customer_name: Pecks Farm Market II East LLC
site_name: Pecks Farm Market II East LLC

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Three animals were observed to have thinner body condition at the facility; a brown cow, red and white steer, and a fallow
deer doe tag#0196. Per representatives the brown cow had been separated to another pasture around August 11 to
monitor her grain intake better and provide extra grain. I had concerns with the amount of grain being fed to the brown
cow was more than a standard diet and consulted with the attending veterinarian who agreed that the amount of grain
described could cause health problems. The red and white steer and fallow deer also have grain and corn as a large
portion of their diet. Inappropriate amounts of grain could cause health problems in the mentioned animals. Appropriate
diets as guided by the attending veterinarian must be in place for body condition maintainence. The facility must contact
the attending veterinarian to evaluate the affected animals and obtain and follow the attending veterinarian's guidance
daily to ensure that these animals are receiving an appropriate daily diet.
***Correct by 8/27/2025.

Records were not up to date to indicate changes in animals numbers at the facility including the number of ducks,
peafowl, llamas, goats, Barbados sheep and chickens. Up to date and accurate records can be important for animal
husbandry tracking. Records must be kept up to date to reflect dates of acquisition/disposition, name and address from
whom animals are acquired or transferred and dates of disposition.
***Correct from 8/21/2025 forward.

Visitors were observed able to feed and pet animals in areas that were not visible to the store manager who also serves
as the attendant. A readily identifiable attendant/employee must be present at times of public contact to ensure the safety
of the animals and the public. Ensure that a responsible, knowledgeable and readily identifiable employee or attendant is
present at all times during periods of public contact.
***Correct by 8/28/2025.

Animal pens had areas in need of repair/maintainenance to prevent areas that can cause injury.
-Wood from a broken pallet in the bison pen had nails sticking up.
-A hog panel was on the ground in the brown cow's pen that she could step on.
-Shelters in the sheep pen had rusted edges that were rough/sharp.
-A screwpoint was sticking out of the automatic feeder that goats could touch.
-An old pallet was in front of the drinking area for the white-tailed deer.
-An old broken pallet with exposed nailheads was in the fallow-deer drinking water area.
-Shelters by the pot-bellied pig/billy goat pens had loose chicken wire.
Areas with points, rusted rough edges, and exposed nails can cause injury to animals. Ensure that all areas that animals
live in are maintained in good repair to prevent possible injury to animals.
***Correct by 8/25/2025.

The brown cow's pasture lacks adequate shelter from sunlight. There is a shelterbelt of trees that could provide some
shade part of the day, but otherwise she does not have access to shade at all times of day. Lack of access to a
shade/shelter can cause discomfort to animals. Ensure that an adequate shelter that provides shelter from sunlight is
provided.
***Correct by 8/27/2025

The steer and billy goat pen has three areas where excess water has pooled and has green material growing in the
pooled water. While the animals have do have access to dry shelter, excess water pooling in their living space can cause
disease hazards and increase areas where insect pests can multiply. Ensure to maintain methods to rapidly eliminate
excess water from animal living spaces.
***Correct by 9/5/2025.

Areas where grain and produce is fed to the billy goats, cows, and sheep had leftover wet feed material that had flies on it
and had a rotten smell. Maintaining these areas clean is required to help prevent flies and protect animal health by
preventing food contamination. Ensure to maintain a routine of keeping feeding areas clean at all times.
Receptacles/feeders and areas where animals regularly fed must be kept clean and sanitary at all times.
***Correct from 8/21/2025 forward.

Weeds with spiney seed pods have grown over the elk's water bowl to where access to his water bowl could be impeded.
While he still has access to the water overflow that creates a wallow area, the overgrown weeds could make it less
desirable to drink the potable water in the bowl. Ensure that grounds are kept in good repair and free from weed
overgrowth to facilitate normal husbandry practices as required such as access to clean water for the elk.
***Correct by 8/22/2025.

The corn crib areas housing peacocks had areas that need repair. A re-bar was in the west corn crib with a sharp point
sticking in where peafowl can touch it. Multiple areas had loose wire with loose points that could injure peacocks. Ensure
that areas where birds are housed are free from sharp points and maintained in a manner that protects the birds from
possible injury.
***Correct by 8/26/2025.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The written program of enrichment for birds was not available for inspection. A written program of enrichment for birds
that is approved by the attending veterinarian must be in place to ensure birds are provided with appropriate environment
and social grouping. Ensure to work with the attending veterinarian to develop and maintain a written program of
environmental enhancement.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The peacock housed on the east end of the corn crib areas lacked a perch or area that the peafowl could sit up off the
ground if it wanted to. A perching area for peacock provides enrichment for it and an opportunity for it to rest off of the
ground. Ensure that each peacock has access to a perching area as a form of enrichment.
***Correct by 8/29/2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Three animals were observed to have thinner body condition at the facility; a brown cow, red and white steer, and a fallow 
deer doe tag#0196. Per representatives the brown cow had been separated to another pasture around August 11 to

the attending veterinarian to evaluate the affected animals and obtain and follow the attending veterinarian's guidance 
daily to ensure that these animals are receiving an appropriate daily diet.  
***Correct by 8/27/2025. 
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
Records were not up to date to indicate changes in animals numbers at the facility including the number of ducks, 
peafowl, llamas, goats, Barbados sheep and chickens. Up to date and accurate records can be important for animal 
husbandry tracking. Records must be kept up to date to reflect dates of acquisition/disposition, name and address from

2.131(d)(2) 
   
Handling of animals. 
Visitors were observed able to feed and pet animals in areas that were not visible to the store manager who also serves 
as the attendant. A readily identifiable attendant/employee must be present at times of public contact to ensure the safety 
of the animals and the public. Ensure that a responsible, knowledgeable and readily identifiable employee or attendant is 
present at all times during periods of public contact.  
***Correct by 8/28/2025. 
3.125(a)

Facilities, general. 
Animal pens had areas in need of repair/maintainenance to prevent areas that can cause injury.  
-Wood from a broken pallet in the bison pen had nails sticking up.  
-A hog panel was on the ground in the brown cow's pen that she could step on. 
-Shelters in the sheep pen had rusted edges that were rough/sharp.  
-A screwpoint was sticking out of the automatic feeder that goats could touch.  
-An old pallet was in front of the drinking area for the white-tailed deer.  
-An old broken pallet with exposed nailheads was in the fallow-deer drinking water area.  
-Shelters by the pot-bellied pig/billy goat pens had loose chicken wire. 
 
Areas with points, rusted rough edges, and exposed nails can cause injury to animals. Ensure that all areas that animals 
live in are maintained in good repair to prevent possible injury to animals.  
***Correct by 8/25/2025. 
3.127(a) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The brown cow's pasture lacks adequate shelter from sunlight. There is a shelterbelt of trees that could provide some 
shade part of the day, but otherwise she does not have access to shade at all times of day. Lack of access to a 
shade/shelter can cause discomfort to animals. Ensure that an adequate shelter that provides shelter from sunlight is

***Correct by 8/27/2025 
3.127(c) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The steer and billy goat pen has three areas where excess water has pooled and has green material growing in the 
pooled water. While the animals have do have access to dry shelter, excess water pooling in their living space can cause 
disease hazards and increase areas where insect pests can multiply. Ensure to maintain methods to rapidly eliminate 
excess water from animal living spaces.  
***Correct by 9/5/2025. 
3.129(b) 
   
Feeding. 
Areas where grain and produce is fed to the billy goats, cows, and sheep had leftover wet feed material that had flies on it 
and had a rotten smell. Maintaining these areas clean is required to help prevent flies and protect animal health by 
preventing food contamination. Ensure to maintain a routine of keeping feeding areas clean at all times. 
Receptacles/feeders and areas where animals regularly fed must be kept clean and sanitary at all times.

3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation.

Weeds with spiney seed pods have grown over the elk's water bowl to where access to his water bowl could be impeded. 
While he still has access to the water overflow that creates a wallow area, the overgrown weeds could make it less

***Correct by 8/22/2025. 
3.153(a)(1)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The corn crib areas housing peacocks had areas that need repair. A re-bar was in the west corn crib with a sharp point 
sticking in where peafowl can touch it. Multiple areas had loose wire with loose points that could injure peacocks. Ensure 
that areas where birds are housed are free from sharp points and maintained in a manner that protects the birds from 
possible injury.  
***Correct by 8/26/2025. 
3.154  Repeat
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The written program of enrichment for birds was not available for inspection. A written program of enrichment for birds 
that is approved by the attending veterinarian must be in place to ensure birds are provided with appropriate environment 
and social grouping. Ensure to work with the attending veterinarian to develop and maintain a written program of 
environmental enhancement. 
3.154(b) 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The peacock housed on the east end of the corn crib areas lacked a perch or area that the peafowl could sit up off the 
ground if it wanted to. A perching area for peacock provides enrichment for it and an opportunity for it to rest off of the 
ground. Ensure that each peacock has access to a perching area as a form of enrichment.  
***Correct by 8/29/2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives
